sentences.sentence: “In you come, sir—you and your friends,” he answered. “Very sorry, Mr. Thaddeus, but my orders are very strict. Had to be certain of your friends before I let them in.”
Inside, a gravel( 碎石 ) path wound through desolate( 荒凉的 ) grounds to a huge house, all in darkness except where some moonlight was reflected in an attic( 阁楼 ) window.
The vast size of the building, with its gloom( 昏暗 ) and its deathly silence, struck a chill( 寒冷 ) to my heart.
Thaddeus Sholto also seemed ill at ease( 局促不安的 ), and the lantern shook in his hand.
“I cannot understand it,” he said. “There must be some mistake.
I distinctly told Bartholomew that we would be here, and yet there is no light in his window.
I do not know what to make of( 理解 ) it.”
“Does he always guard the property in this way?” asked Holmes.
“Yes, he has followed my father’s custom.
He was the favorite son, you know, and I sometimes think that my father may have told him more than he ever told me.
That is Bartholomew’s window up there where the moonlight shines. It is quite bright, but there is no light from inside, I think.”
“None,” said Holmes. “But I see a light in that little window beside the door.”
“Ah, that is the housekeeper’s room. That is where old Mrs. Bernstone sits. She can tell us all about it.
But perhaps you would not mind waiting here for a minute or two, for if we all go in together she may be alarmed. But what is that sound?”
Miss Morstan seized my wrist, and we all stood with thumping hearts, straining our ears( 努力地听 ).
From the great black house there sounded through the silent night the saddest and most pitiful of sounds—the whimpering of a frightened( 受惊的 ) woman.
“It is Mrs. Bernstone,” said Sholto. “She is the only woman in the house. Wait here. I shall be back in a moment.”
He hurried for the door, and knocked in his peculiar( 奇怪的 ) way. We could see a tall old woman let him in.
“Oh, Mr. Thaddeus, sir, I am so glad you have come! I am so glad you have come, Mr. Thaddeus, sir!” she said as she closed the door behind him.
Our guide had left us the lantern.
Holmes swung it slowly round, and looked closely at the house, and at the great rubbish-heaps all around the property.
Miss Morstan and I stood together, and her hand was in mine.
A wonderfully subtle( 微妙的 ) thing is love, for here were we two who had never seen each other before that day, between whom no word or even look of affection had ever passed,
and yet now in an hour of trouble our hands instinctively sought for each other.
I have marveled at( 对这感到惊奇 ) it since, but at the time it seemed the most natural thing that I should go out to her so,
and, as she has often told me, there was in her also the instinct( 本能 ) to turn to me for comfort and protection.
So we stood hand in hand, like two children, and there was peace in our hearts, despite all the dark things that surrounded us.
“What a strange place!” she said, looking round.
“It looks as though all the moles in England had been let loose( 任自由行动 ) in it.
I have seen something of the sort on the side of a hill near Ballarat, where the searchers for gold had been at work.”
“And from the same cause,” said Holmes. “These are the traces( 迹象 ) of the treasure-seekers. You must remember that they were six years looking for it.
No wonder that the grounds look like a gravel-pit( 采砾坑 ).”
At that moment the door of the house burst open( 突然打开 ), and Thaddeus Sholto came running out, with terror in his eyes.
“There is something wrong with Bartholomew!” he cried. “I am terrified! My nerves( 神经 ) cannot stand it.”
He was, indeed, half crying with fear, and his feeble( 虚弱的 ) face peeping out from his great coat had the helpless appealing expression of a terrified child.
“Come into the house,” said Holmes, in his firm way.
“Yes, do!” pleaded( 请求 ) Thaddeus Sholto. “I really do not feel up to( 感觉有能力 ) giving orders.”
We all followed him into the housekeeper’s room, which stood upon the left-hand side of the passage.
The old woman was pacing up and down with a terrified look and restless fingers, but the sight of Miss Morstan appeared to have a calming effect upon her.
“God bless your sweet calm face!” she cried, with a hysterical( 歇斯底里的 ) sob. “It does me good to see you. Oh, but I have had such a shock this day!”
Our companion patted( 轻拍 ) her thin, work-worn hand, and murmured( 小声说 ) some few words of kindly womanly comfort which brought the color back into the other’s bloodless cheeks.
“Master has locked himself in and will not answer me,” she explained.
“All day I waited to hear from him, for he often likes to be alone; but an hour ago I feared that something was wrong, so I went up and looked through the key-hole.
You must go up, Mr. Thaddeus—you must go up and look for yourself.
I have known Mr. Bartholomew Sholto for ten years, but I never saw him with such a face as that.”
Sherlock Holmes took the lamp and led the way.
So shaken was Thaddeus Sholto that I had to pass my hand under his arm as we went up the stairs, for his knees were trembling under him.
Twice as we ascended( 攀登（楼梯） ) Holmes took his lens( 透镜 ) out of his pocket and carefully examined marks which appeared to me to be mere shapeless smudges of dust upon the stair-carpet.
He walked slowly from step to step, holding the lamp, and looking closely to right and left.
Miss Morstan had remained behind with the frightened( 受惊的 ) housekeeper.
